review_title: VPs and Directors never leave but high turn around for lower level staff
job_title: Manager in Napa, CA

cons: Employee turn around is very high. VPs and Directors never leave and are out of touch. They dont care about the success of newer employees. They will expect you to work night and day for a barely livable salary. Grid culture is real and so unhealthy.

review_title: The Best Institute at Money Making
job_title: Undergraduate Student in Hyde Park, NY
pros: The Hyde Park campus is beautiful. It is a quiet place to live, with a lot of greens and trees. I enjoy the weather a lot besides winter. If you like nature, you will enjoy the Hyde Park campus. Lots of food options. Great chefs and a lot of friendly people.
cons: The CIA management is awful and disorganized. The orientation was painful for the welcome team and orientation leaders because of their poor management. The CIA required students to move out of summer so they could clean and remodel the dorm. However, the dorms weren't clean and fixed at all, all the money went to making the campus look pretty so that when new students came, their parents could be impressed. When new students move in, their bunk bed is broken or without ladders. Water fountains at the dorm are broken for at least 2 semesters, and they still haven't been fixed yet so people need to get water from the egg to refill or somewhere else to buy them. The CIA spent a lot of money creating new school logos, changing uniforms, making the campus look nice, and building their hotels. The outside looks fabulous, but the inside is rotten. The CIA is short-staffed (chefs, professors) yet takes more students than usual. The CulSci program is a good example because they only have four instructors. They condense the program, so there is much information in one class. It is confusing when they expect you to know the things that weren't taught to you before. Hard for one instructor to manage 20+ students in a small lab. One chef instructor has been teaching for 30 years and no longer has enthusiasm for teaching. They don't care about how the students can learn better. It's none of their business and it's never their fault the student didn't understand them. The CIA's kitchen classes are getting easier because they want students to move on to bachelor's degrees. Yet, their academic classes are not strong because it is just a culinary school, and again they are not hiring enough instructors. Students are diverse, but the faculties are not. If you have any incidents or things to report, you will find out they run very bureaucratically, and they never keep you in the loop. They charge students a lot -- they get wholesale price or sponsored but they charge 28 points (dollars) for the case of 12 water bottles and 10 points for 10 cans of sparkling water?

review_title: Solid work opportunities but very different educational environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hyde Park, NY
pros: Fabulous food, exciting campus events, and standard benefits. Many famous people visit the campus. The prestige of the school is a draw for many applicants.
cons: This is a very different place in terms of the higher education environment. The school is run on a corporate model which may not be for everyone. Recruitment and retention are major goals on the campus. Those who don't like change and a three-week class rotation (six-week and twelve-week for a few courses like writing), will have a difficult time here.

job_title: Admissions Officer in Hyde Park, NY
pros: Decent benefits and pretty nice campus
cons: There are so many to list. Management is extremely unprofessional and full of favoritism. They promote from within rather than hiring someone qualified even if they are from the outside. Managers are not qualified and are extremely unorganized. The institution is corrupt with higher ups filling their pockets. The staff is full of people nervous about losing their jobs because enrollment has been down for the past five years. You are expected to work absurd hours and are micromanaged in all areas of your job because of their lack of trust. Don't be surprised if you get bashed by your manager behind your back - it is a normal occurrence. If you choose to work here - the arrogance that many members of the staff have is a huge turn off and many of them believe the world would stop turning if the CIA closed. So my advice, if you got a job here or are considering applying take your application and walk in the opposite direction. Go to Johnson and Wales - I hear they are a much better place to work and at least they respect their employees.

review_title: Need to take better care of their employees
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Free meals, a good amount of holidays, 401K, medical, beautiful setting
cons: Rising medical costs, very strict budget concerns lead to insufficient resources and increased pressure. There are hardly any employee events, just the occasional luncheon, but we got free lunch every day anyway. Seems like more and more of the aspects that they sell you on are going away- Insurance used to be free- now cost and arm and a leg, Causal dress during school downtime but only if you hid up on the 3rd floor and don't see the public and there is a strong pressure to not dress causally. Employee complain all the time but just kept hearing there was nothing they could do because of budget. Minimal cost of living raise annually that didn't cover the rise in medical benefits for the year

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Hyde Park, NY
pros: Though there are many culinary programs out there now, The CIA is still one of the best schools on the world. They continue to expand their degree programs and attract many top students. The facility is beautiful and the Hudson Valley is a great place to work and live.  The school has a generous benefits package for full time employees.
cons: Unfortunately, like many other colleges, The CIA has cut a lot of full-time faculty positions and relies more heavily on adjuncts. I think that has affected the quality of the eduction. Also the pay for adjuncts is very low and they are not provided with benefits.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Prestige of working at the best culinary school in the world. Beautiful campus. Opportunity to try great food from all over the world. A few of the higher-ups are good mentors who provide encouragement and solid advice. Some of the co-workers are fun!
cons: If you're not an instructor or a director-level employee, you're regarded as disposable. Many of the chef-instructors are haughty and dismissive. Poor communication between departments. Some of the directors provide little guidance or mentorship to employees. You can go very high here if you're a CIA graduate. If not, it depends on how much your supervisor advocates for you. This is an institution, with all the pluses and minuses that come with it; change is very slow to come.

job_title: Student Services in Hyde Park, NY
pros: The pros of working there was the beautiful campus. The facilities are kept extremely clean and everything looks beautiful and happy except for the faces of the employees who are working there. It's all smoke and mirrors. A beautiful facade with terrible treatment of employees underneath.
cons: Completely inflexible about getting time off. Management dictated when vacation time could be used. The "management" style is based on intimidation and harassment. They like to remind hard working and valuable staff that they are an "at-will employer." The low morale is rampant throughout the institution and even the students feel it. It is a shame since it has a beautiful campus and beautiful buildings, but the administration is the worst! A hostile work environment! Horrible leadership. Promotions seemed based on politics not talent and hard work.

review_title: Striving for Excellence but Far From Reaching It
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hyde Park, NY
pros:
The students are amazing and truly want to make the most out of their experience. 
The teachers are fully committed to the students.
I thought the benefits were fair during my time as an employee.
cons:
- Unethical oversight by management.
- The individuals in the human resources department are substantially ill-placed and ill-equipped to be dealing with personnel on any level. 
- If you are looking for a "higher education" atmosphere, this is not the place to be.
- A blind-eye is turned to sexist, inappropriate and unethical behavior by management.
- Management salaries reflect more of a corporate structure than a "not for profit" institution. They would rather see entire groups of employees be laid off then see a deduction in their personal income.
- Extreme amount of employee turn-over.
- The facade of Excellence if more important than the actual values which they deem to follow

review_title: A culture of employee frustration and distrust
job_title: Consumer Services in Saint Helena, CA
pros: CIA status is high. The opportunity to interact with very high-end culinary professionals and budding chefs. Great exposure to learn about and taste foods from all over the world. Decent benefits, some great hardworking team members who really care about the school's mission and values.
cons: Departments do not work in unison, but are competing and pitched against each other. High level of frustration among faculty and staff. Horrible employee culture and backstabbing. The Managing Director of the CIA Greystone campus, Thomas Bensel, highly favors some employees and degrades others publicly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Napa, CA
pros: If you love food and wine, this is your mecca. There's no better place to go if you love the idea of converging education with the culinary arts. The facilities are beautiful and one-of-a-kind. You feel a sense of importance working for a such an iconic institution.
cons: The CIA is an older organization and slow to evolve. There's a lot of pressure to perform, but minimal resources or strategic direction from management.

review_title: Beautiful on the Outside, Not So Much on the Inside
job_title: in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Free meals for staff, beautiful setting, small campuses allows for staff and students to really communicate and get to know one another.
cons:
Management - it always seemed like there was a constant inability to think logically for the betterment of the students by management. Conferences would take up classrooms on lecture days and displace students, increase student enrollment without adequate housing space to accommodate everyone, and decisions made for Greystone and San Antonio campuses are by higher ups in Hyde Park thousands of miles away with no integral knowledge of how the other campuses actually work and will be affected.

Morale - Staff morale was always low. Managers always spoke about budget and cutting costs, so there was rarely any staff events or bonding - those that did exist were usually courtesy of Housing throwing an event for students that included staff (i.e. Kickball game or Winter Dance.)

Deaf Ears - no complaint is ever properly addressed. Any complaint I would have would be responded to with a clearly automated response by managers or directors. Nothing was ever done for large, glaring issues and opinions of employees simply fell on deaf ears. It was very much a mentality that leaders would hear you, but not listen to you, smile and nod when appropriate, and disregard everything the second you left.

Retention - For several reasons listed above, staff retention is low. Staff changes of main positions occur so much for a myriad of reasons: low pay, low morale, bad manager, etc. Students take notice too, and it makes them uneasy.

review_title: Poor Communication, Bad work culture as result of favoritism and antic behavior
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hyde Park, NY
pros:
Worked with industry experts teaching staff.
Wonderfully talented maintenance and IT Staff.
Beautiful and well maintained Campus.
cons:
Degrading leadership. 
Unprofessional employees in professional roles. 
Shared Adversary between departments.
and much more......

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Napa, CA
pros:
- Beautiful, top of the line facilities.
- Hard working, supportive, and helpful peers in CA (for the most part).
- Decent benefits if you are in the right benefit group.
- Good retirement plan (up to 4% match after 1 year of employment).
- Management has decent ideas on how to bring the public into the building, only downside is that usually means current employees have to work harder and longer hours to accommodate. 
- Lots of career opportunities because the turnover rate is so high.
cons:
- Lack of communication at all levels.
- Extremely low employee morale.
- Employees are dispensable in the eyes of upper management and are treated as such.
- Little to no training.
- Inconsistent procedures. One day you are told to do something one way and the next you are told you are wrong and told to do it a completely different way. Then you are lectured for not knowing how to do your job. This inconsistent behavior comes from the NY team, which controls the CA operations.
- Not fair to all employees. Admin employees get much better benefits and incentives than those who are public operations. 
- Employees are over worked and under appreciated. 
- Very unorganized.
- Reorgs often. They don't tend to let employee's go due to reorgs (probably because they happen so often) but it does throw off operations and how to run things efficiently. 
- Low pay. I, personally, was making $10,000 less a year compared to others in my position, in the valley, with my experience. 
- CA campus is controlled by the NY team, which is where the majority of the negativity stems from. They do not know the atmosphere, culture, or needs of the CA team but we could not make any decisions without their approval beforehand.

review_title: Great coworkers, management not so much
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newburgh, NY
pros: So many people feel so strongly about the work they do in support of the students, it is heartwarming. Campus is beautiful.
cons: No longer an organization that cares about its employees. Increasingly corporate attitude where money is all that matters. Moral of employees is on a steep decline.

review_title: This place is a hell hole. A nightmare.  Run away
job_title: Manager in Hyde Park, NY
pros: Very nice campus, but that does not overcome all the cons
cons: Do not leave your job to start working here. It is a big mistake.  You will be in a worse situation. Management is constantly violating labor laws, they harass employees, terminate with no warning or documentation.  An employment lawyer would become rich if they set up an office across the street.

review_title: Little Room for Growth; Lacks Organization; Disgruntled Employees
job_title: Manager in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Free Food, Good Benefits, Beautiful View (if you are one of the chosen few with a window)
cons: Many positions are revolving doors. Morale is low, and departments do not work well with one another. There is little to no positive reinforcement, and people are quick to throw people under the bus to prevent public degradation. The computer systems are archaic and make production slow and tedious. Systems exist just because "that's the way we have always done it." The greed of management is transparent in everything that we do. Don't have kitchen space? Find it; add another class. Students = $$. We have 10 conferences a year and we have burned out all the staff? Hire new staff; add two conferences. Conferences = $$.

review_title: Do your research and read the reviews!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hyde Park, IN
pros:
-Great co-workers depending on the department that you're in. I met some fantastic people that taught me a lot and were fun to work with.
-The students are fantastic! It's great interacting with them and seeing them grow during their time at the CIA.
-The food! It's pretty obvious but this is one of the biggest pros of the job.
-If you live in the Hudson Valley it's a really easy commute.
cons:
-LOW Pay: You're expected to work and produce excellent work with little to no financial incentive. Basically you can expect to work really hard with a VERY SMALL pay raise. 

-Upper Management: There's a lack of communication from the executive management team. Strategies don't often get shared with the teams that are expected to execute them. This can often make it feel like you're working with a blind fold on. Also, their attitude toward the people that do the day to day work needs to be worked on, often times they can very negative towards them. 

-Work Environment: This may depend on the team that you're in. But tensions and uncertainty can be felt and seen. It contributes to a really stressful environment to work in.

-Communication: This can relate back to the executive management feedback above. Apart from that people don't feel like speaking their mind will make an impact or be heard. In addition to this information is very siloed across teams.

-Training/Development: There's no training or career development available for teams to participate in. 

-Tools: Because the organization is a not-for-profit it feels like budgets for tool updates/acquirements aren't prioritized. This makes it frustrating when excellent results are expected with a limited tool box.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hyde Park, NY
pros: It’s the people you work with that keep you coming back especially if you’ve been there for several years.
cons: There is a blatant lack of respect for anyone unless you are part of “the inner circle”. Thinking for yourself, any kind of autonomy or professional growth is a thing of the past. People work in fear of losing their jobs every day when a select few benefit from laying people off.
